title: The human dorsal anterior cingulate facilitates acceptance of unfair offers and regulates inequity aversion
reasoning_research: The study employs a rigorous multi-method approach combining fMRI, computational modeling (DDM), and behavioral analysis within the established Ultimatum Game paradigm. The methodology explicitly links model parameters (DDM weight for DI) to neural measures (dACC representations, dACC-vlPFC connectivity) and behavioral outcomes, demonstrating a clear analytical chain. The sample size and preregistration status are not specified, limiting a full assessment of robustness.
reasoning_impact: The findings directly challenge traditional reward-maximization accounts of bargaining by proposing a specific neural circuit (dACC-vlPFC) for regulating inequity aversion to facilitate socially pragmatic decisions. This offers a novel, mechanistic framework for understanding self-control in social economic games, potentially redirecting theory on how cognitive control systems manage social emotions like unfairness.

title: The Difficulty in Numerical Computation Impacts Motor Decisions in a Stop-Signal Task
reasoning_research: The study employs a novel task design (NC-SST) to manipulate cognitive demand via numerical distance, uses a computational model (generalized drift-diffusion model) to analyze data, and reports a sample size of 32 participants. reasoning_impact: The work directly links cognitive difficulty in numerical processing to motor initiation and inhibition, core components of decision-making and self-control.
